title: Electric flux - graph of squares flux vs unknown x

content.question: A square area of side length <math alttext="s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>s</mi></math> is in a region of space that has a uniform electric field of magnitude <math alttext="E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>E</mi></math>, as shown in the figure. The field is at an angle <math alttext="theta sub N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>θ</mi><mi>N</mi></msub></math> from the normal to the square’s surface, and an angle <math alttext="theta sub P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>θ</mi><mi>P</mi></msub></math> from the plane of the square. The graph shows the magnitude <math alttext="phi" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi></math> of the electric flux through the square as a function of an unknown variable <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>. Which of the following quantities could <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math> represent?

unit.text: 8: Electric Charges, Fields, and Gauss's Law

skill.text: 3.B: Apply an appropriate law, definition, theoretical relationship, or model to make a claim.
